<!--
**Lemma -- Inner/Outer Decomposition.**
Let $f: A(c,r_1, r_2) \to \mathbb{C}$ be a holomorphic function defined
on some non-empty open annulus.
There are holomorphic functions 
$\phi:D(0,r_2) \mapsto \mathbb{C}$
and $\psi: D(0,1/r_1) \mapsto \mathbb{C}$ such that $\psi(0) = 0$ and
  $$
  \forall \, z \in A(0,r_1,r_2), \; f(z) = \phi(z-c) + \psi((z-c)^{-1}). 
  $$

**Proof -- Inner/Outer Decomposition.**
For the sake of simplicity we assume that $c=0.$
Let $z \in A(0, r_1, r_2)$ and $\rho_1,\rho_2 \in \left]r_1,r_2\right[$
such that $\rho_1 <|z| < \rho_2.$ 
Cauchy's integral formula provides
  $$
  f(z) = 
  \frac{1}{i2\pi} \int_{\rho_2[\circlearrowleft]} \frac{f(w)}{w-z} \, dw
  -
  \frac{1}{i2\pi} \int_{\rho_1[\circlearrowleft]} \frac{f(w)}{w-z} \, dw
  $$
The path $\rho_1[\circlearrowleft]$ is the image of the path
$\rho_1^{-1} [\circlearrowleft]^{\leftarrow}$ by the holomorphic function
 $z \in \mathbb{C}^* \mapsto 1/z,$ hence
  $$
  \begin{split}
  -\frac{1}{i2\pi} \int_{\rho_1[\circlearrowleft]} \frac{f(w)}{w-z} \, dw
  &= 
  \frac{1}{i2\pi} 
  \int_{\rho_1^{-1} [\circlearrowleft]}
  \frac{f(1/v)}{1/v - z} \frac{-dv}{v^2} \\
  &=
  z^{-1}\frac{1}{i2\pi} 
  \int_{\rho_1^{-1} [\circlearrowleft]}
  \frac{f(1/v)/v}{v -z^{-1}} dv.
  \end{split}
  $$
Define $\phi:D(0,r_2) \mapsto \mathbb{C}$ 
and $\psi: D(0,1/r_1) \mapsto \mathbb{C}$ by
  $$
  \phi(z) = \frac{1}{i2\pi} \int_{\rho_2[\circlearrowleft]} \frac{f(w)}{w-z} \, dw
  \; \mbox{ and } \;
  \psi(\xi) = \xi \frac{1}{i2\pi} \int_{\rho_1^{-1}[\circlearrowleft]} \frac{f(1/v)/v}{v-\xi} \, dv
  $$
where $\rho_1$ and $\rho_2$ -- that depend on $z$ -- are selected such that 
$|z| < \rho_2 < r_2$ and $|\xi| < \rho_1^{-1} < r_1^{-1};$ 
by Cauchy's integral theorem, the two line integrals
are independent of the selection of these radii as along as the inequalities 
hold, thus the definition of $\phi$ and $\psi$ is unambiguous.
Both integrals may expanded as convergent power series
(refer to the proof of the power series expansion theorem),
therefore both functions are holomorphic.
It is also plain that for any $z\in A(0,\rho_1, \rho_2),$
we have $f(z) = \phi(z) + \psi(z^{-1})$ and $\psi(0) = 0.$
\hfill $\blacksquare$
-->
\forall \, z\in A(c, r_1, r_2), \; f(z) = \sum_{n=-\infty}^{+\infty} a_n (z-c)^n.
